column5: Fix php cli (-S option) inconsistent port parsing
column9:
## Description

The php cli server (-S) option parser uses strtol(3) to retrieve the port
from address argument. Therefore, htons(3) is used to normalize the
address port, which leads to an unverified cast.

The issue may appear trivial, therefore, assumi

column5: Bug #34380: preserve errno for stream_select and stream_socket_pair
column9:
When the system calls underneath stream_select() and stream_socket_pair()
fail, errno is logged but is not preserved. This change preservers errno in
posix_globals to allow the caller to query posix_get_last_error() to determine
the cause of the failure.

column5: Opcache: Fix segfault while pre-evaluating a disabled function
column9:
Opcache pass 1 accesses func->module in the "pre-evaluate constant functions"-step. However if the function has been disabled func->module will be NULL.

I think this will fix https://bugs.php.net/bug.php?id=68104

This is the way file streams do it and apparently some filter algorithms as convert.base64-encode depend on it.

column5: Crypt error-condition fixes
column9:
Crypt is currently documented to fail if provided invalid salts for STD_DES. The current implementation does not do so.

This can cause `crypt` to become silently insecure by falling back to STD_DES if there is a mistake in the salt format for another alg

column5: Core: Fix nodeName-related issues
column9:
### Summary ###
The jQuery.nodeName deprecation (ac9e3016) introduced a few serious regressions.

column5: Add reduce to deopted methods
column9:
All of our currently deoptimized Underscore methods (`pick`, `omit`, `invoke`, `without`, and `difference`) change behavior based on the number of arguments pass to the call. This both adds `reduce` (and friends).

Supersedes (and incorporates) #3810.

column5: Reduce without initial value doesn't work
column9:
Underscore's reduce as well as native Array.prototype.reduce can work without initial value.

See two similar calls:

``` js
equal(_.reduce(col.models, function(a, b) {return a.id > b.id ? a : b}).id, 3); // works fine
equal(col.reduce(function(a, b) {ret

column5: fix error when adding model to collection at an out of bounds index

Fixes an issue noticed when running Marionette tests against 1.2.2. Adding a model at index 5 to a collection with a length of 3 throws an error. Previously this would add to the end of the collection.

column5: Ensure a search test fails when appropriate.

Steve

Nick

column5: Fix locking in GetTransaction.

This is likely unnecessary

column5: Make sure we re-acquire lock if a task throws
column9:
This fixes #6394

Pretty simple, it just makes sure to re-acquire the lock in case f throws, so that we don't touch nThreadsServicingQueue without the lock. The empty throw statement re-raises the current exception.

- The use of `/x` where 8 does not divide x was broken, due to a bit-order issue

column5: Parameter interaction: disable upnp if -proxy set
column9:
To protect privacy, do not use UPNP when a proxy is set. The user may still specify `-listen=1` to listen locally (for a hidden service), so don't rely on this happening via the `-listen` case.

Fixes #2927.

column5: Do not inv old or missing blocks when pruning

When responding to a getblocks message, only return inv's as

that we are likely to not delete in the near future.

column5: Avoid crash on start in TestBlockValidity with gen=1 (rework)
column9:

When the internal miner is enabled at the start of a new node, there is an near instant assert in TestBlockValidity because its attempting to mine a block before the top checkpoint.

Also avoids a data race around vNodes.

It should be checked again immediately before sending coins to prevent
the user from paying to an expired invoice which would then req

column5: Catch UTXO set read errors and shutdown
column9:
This is a minimally invasive patch to shutdown on LevelDB read errors from the chainstate. The block index does not need similar protection, as it's only read at startup.

Should apply cleanly to 0.10 as well.

column5: rpcserver: attempt to fix uncaught exception.
column9:
Addresses #5560.

`asio::ip::address::to_string()` can throw in some cases, which I believe winxp may be hitting.

I've simulated the case locally by adding:

```
            if (bindAddress.is_v6())
            {
                boost::system::error_code

column5: signrawtransaction: validate private key.
column9: Fix issue #5454. Validate private key is inside allowed range.

column5: Make -printblocktree compatible with headers first
column9: Alternative: delete -printblocktree. I didn't even know it still existed.

column5: Check block header when accepting headers from peers.
column9:
Actually check block headers received from peers.  If a peer sends headers with invalid PoW, they were accepted and added to the disk block index previously.  This would then lead to a failure in checking the PoW
during the next startup while loading the

column5: Fix coinbase-spend mempool inconsistency after reorgs
column9: We were previously not removing transactions from mempool during reorg if they spent a coinbase. While this broke the mempool-invariant of safe-to-put-in-next-block it doesnt matter as mining code double-checks anyway (unless you're running with -debug or

column5: Sleep-wait on genesis block during init with -reindex
column9: This is an alternative to #5078...instead of throwing when chainActive.Tip() is missing (breaking what has otherwise traditionally been a global assumption) we just wait until at least genesis has been imported (its always first).

column5: Reset setBlockIndexCandidates once block index db loaded
column9: Delete all entries in setBlockIndexCandidates that are worse than our new current block upon completion of the initial LoadBlockIndexDB.

column5: Fix -loadblock after partial IBD and init after kill -9
column9:
You can currently kill -9 during IBD and will not be able to restart.
Also, if you let IBD start and then try to -loadblock afterwards it will not connect any of the blocks.

column5: Fix IsInitialBlockDownload which was broken by headers first.
Introduce preferred download peers
column9: Keep track of whether we have peers that are preferred candidates for downloading blocks from, but if there are none, also use others.

column5: Check pindexBestForkBase for null
column9: This addresses an edge case where pindexBestForkBase is not previously set. Longer term, the logic further upstream in ActivateBestChainStep needs to be reworked.

column5: Write fee estimate and peers files only when initialized
column9:
Fixes #4669 (see discussion there).

Also move the loading of addresses to StartNode() to make it more self-contained.

column5: UniValue: fix major bug, add unit tests
column9: All numbers were broken, due to lack of an underscore.  No wonder my all-tree conversion to UniValue was failing its tests.

column5: Don't poll showmyip.com, it doesn't exist anymore
column9:
This was bound to happen someday. That leaves us with only one candidate, checkip.dyndns.org.
GetMyExternalIP should be phased out as soon as possible (resurrect #3461 / #3088).

This should also go into 0.9.3.

column5: CCoinsKeyHasher::operator() should return size_t
column9:
It currently returns uint64_t, which on older boost (at least 1.46) causes failures on 32-bit systems. This problem was introduced in bc42503.

Fixes #4634.

column5: script.h: set_vch() should shift a >32 bit value
column9: Source: http://www.viva64.com/en/b/0268/

column5: Fix feeestimate
column9:
-Fix bug where we were checking index value against the wrong vector size. This could cause the wrong value to be returned or to return an out of bounds value.
-Move the clearing of the sorted sample vectors to before the debug logging. The debug logging

column5: Check signatures before double-spend relay
column9:
After it passes anti-DoS checks, mark a respend as relayable, but do not actually relay it until after the inputs are completely checked (for valid signatures especially).

This fixes a problem with #3883.

column5: Fix incorrect checkpoint data for testnet3
clear path cache after getting a proper config file (fixes #2605)
column9: should fix #2605, retest please.

column5: Increase the size of adressbookpage.ui in order to fix issue #1062
column9:
The buttons at the bottom of the window are too small for the text they contain if the French locale is used, as discussed on issue #1062. This resizing seems to fix the problem, a screenshot showing the result follows:

![Desktop screenshot with the main

column5: new splash screen image (fix for #1064)
column9:
I consider this a proposal to fix #1064 to not have the bad resize quality, when resizing the current splash screen image. I know we want to get rid of the splash screen in the future, but perhaps this is worth a quick discussion.

I was not too sure abou

column5: Fix many sign-comparison warnings found in bitcoin codebase
column9:
Sign comparison warnings are the largest class of warnings remaining.  These commits fix many of the warnings -- which were indeed valid.

The commits were broken up to make reviewing easier.

column5: Locking fix for AlreadyHave()
column9:
Access to mapTransactions[] must be guarded by cs_mapTransactions lock.

Also, reformat long lines to make the switch statement more readable.

column5: RPC: do not launch Shutdown in a new thread in case we are running the UI
column9: This leads to the bitcoin core being shut down while the UI is accessing it, and generally results in a segmentation fault or crash. In case it is desirable to make it possible to shutdown the GUI from its RPC server, we'll need to implement a signal for

column5: Added a workaround for an Ubuntu bug which causes -fstack-protector-all t
column9:
Added a workaround for an Ubuntu bug which causes -fstack-protector-all to be disregarded.
this causes some functions not to be protected and leads to a warning:
"warning: not protecting function: no buffer at least 8 bytes long"
The bug which this is wor

column5: Bugfix: getmemorypool "bits" should be a hex-string
column9:
Bugfix: "bits" should be a hex-string, not a number (that just doesn't make sense)

(suggest waiting for ACK from original getmemorypool author)

column5: Optimize database writes for transactions with lots of TxIns.
column9:
Patch from ArtForz, who discovered the problem.

The problem was chaining large transactions (transactions with lots of ins and outs) would make the berkeley db transaction log get very big, as the dependencies (TxIns) of a transaction might be re-written

column5: resource leak fix
column9:
Fixed 2 Resource Leaks

http://forum.bitcoin.org/index.php?topic=22585.msg330333#msg330333

column5: Address Book related Fixes
column9:
This is a rebased series of patches from pull request #335

1) Fix the synchronization of sending addresses between a CWallet and its associated CWalletDB (this was reported independently in Issue #350).

2) Add a check for validity of sending addresses (

column5: CWallet: fix mapAddress book update
column9:
Fix update of internal data structure (mapAddressBook) after changes to the address book, and add convenience methods EraseAddressBookName, GetDefaultAddress, SetDefaultAddress to be used from UI.

The problem was introduced in the new CWallet class; mapA

column5: Fix CPU Usage bug when using -nolisten and have no connections.
column9: 1/2 known Windows CPU Usage bugs fixed

column5: non-blocking connect (by phantomcircuit)
column9:
Use non-blocking connects, and a select() call to wait a predefined
time (5s by default, but configurable with -timeout) for either
success or failure. This allows much more connections to be tried
per time unit.

Based on a patch by phantomcircuit.

column5: Fix for small change outputs
column9:
With the separation of CENT and MIN_TX_FEE, it is now reasonable
to create change outputs between 0.01 and 0.0005, as these are
spendable according to the policy, even though they require a fee
to be paid.

Also, when enough fee was already present, every

column5: Remove send to IP address and IP transactions support
column9:
Remove send to IP transaction support, as it is insecure and would confuse users when used. 

An IP is a terrible identifier as it does not identify a person or organization. Furthermore, man-in-the-middle attacks are trivial as the internet has no "proof

column5: listaccounts with minconf param was broken!
column9:
Dumb bug:  listaccounts N ignores the N.

My only excuse is that this is a hard feature to test, because transactions confirmations just keep happening, at unpredictable times...

column5: Add time to category:move transactions
column9: Simple oversight.
